result.text:
基于 @xpg0970 的思路和解析，实验基本成功。
主要思路包括以下几点：

1. 基础素材的准备，也就是首尾帧。就像最终呈现的结果，首帧是一个脏乱差的图片，尾帧是一个最终的装修结果图。基于这个思路，就比较好办了。

如果你有一张比较不错的图（比如你直接把你家的客厅、卧室拍下来，或者之前去网上找精致的装修图）。让AI帮你完成做旧。

提示词如下：
“基于底图，生成一张年久失修，脏乱的室内场景，有很多老旧的家具与肮脏的使用痕迹”
根据需求决定是否要移除家具，如果需要，增加这个提示词：
“移除家具，保留脏乱的毛坯房的效果，但是要注意保持结构的一致性”

这样我们就能获得一张脏乱差的原始底图了。

至于尾帧，我们可以直接用比较好的成果图，如果你觉得你现有的这种照片不够好看，可以让AI帮你进行润色和修改。

提示词参考：
“保持原图视角和墙体结构，生成室内{客厅} 真实渲染图。进行合理的室内家具布置与材质搭配，为室内天花板、墙面、地板分别赋予材质，整体呈现 {现代轻奢风格} 。房间内外均进行真实感渲染。包括 {沙发, 地毯 ,茶几} ，材质质感逼真，光线自然。整体画面呈现出专业建筑摄影的光线效果，具备4K超高清分辨率的图像细节。”

拿到首尾帧之后就可以进行视频生成了，在测试了即梦、可灵、Veo之后。目前最稳定的就是可灵2.6（O1在这个场景下表现一般，不推荐）

视频提示词如下：
房间装修延时摄影视频。工人们在一间简陋的毛坯房内工作，水泥墙面，。快进画面展示：人们清理杂物和垃圾袋、移除所有旧家具，{将房屋还原至毛坯房，擦洗墙壁、将灰色水泥墙刷成现代轻奢风格、先完成主体框架装修，再放入家具，再逐渐将一个房屋搭建成最终的现代轻奢风格的客厅}。多名工人在加速画面中快速移动，工具和材料不断出现又消失，窗外自然光线随时间变化。施工灰尘逐渐落定，从冷蓝色调转变为温暖的环境光。纪实风格，8-16倍速延时，4K画质。

中间的步骤可以再详细点，我这个比较泛用性。这个版本还是可以再次进行迭代的

第二步，垫图第一步生成的满意图片，让它做一张装修整理后的温馨美观房间

第三步，把这两张图片分别作为要生成视频的首帧和尾帧插入到视频生成模型的编辑页面

第四步，把首尾帧图片发给让Claude Opus4.5，让它帮你去做过渡视频的提示词，从图1开始到图2结束画面

result.text:
It's become clear to me over the past few years that almost all government eventually becomes grift.

It all starts innocently enough, with people wanting to fix problems in society.

But, when organizations are stood up that aren't subject to market forces or any type of sunset, they grow without end and are fundamentally inefficient.

It's only a matter of time before that attracts rent-seekers.

Nearly everyone involved has their hand in the honey jar in some way and so excuses for poor performance are made and fraud is covered up. 

Demands are made for more funding but all it does is essentially feed what has become a cancer.

All this can take many many decades, but without a change the way we run government, it's an inevitability.

legacy.description: Prompt Engineer, dedicated to learning and disseminating knowledge about AI, software engineering, and engineering management.

result.text:
这是个好问题：
> 随着基础模型继续进化，Skills 是否会逐渐被更强的自主规划取代？作为创业者现在去布局 Skills，究竟是短期红利还是长期壁垒？

我的看法是：Skills 是短期红利，也是长期壁垒——但壁垒不在 Skills 本身。

让我用 AI 发展的三个阶段来解释这个判断。

第一阶段：AI Chatbot + Prompt

回归第一性原理：AI 也好，Agent 也好，能解决问题才有价值。

最早的 AI Chatbot 加上好的 Prompt，已经能解决很多「生成类」问题——回答问题、情感陪伴、翻译、写作、摘要。

那时候 Prompt 就是短期红利。你会写出好的 Prompt，就能得到好的结果。我那时候花了大量时间研究 Prompt 工程，确实吃到了红利——很多网友就是那时候认识我的。

但要说长期壁垒？没有。现在让 AI 辅助写 Prompt 已经不是什么难事了。

不过，AI Chatbot + Prompt 只能解决生成问题，不能使用工具，不能与外部世界交互。

第二阶段：AI Agent + 上下文工程

然后是 AI Agent 的出现。Agent 能规划、能调用工具，解决了「与环境交互」和「完成特定目标」的问题。

这时候 上下文工程（Context Engineering）就是短期红利。你知道怎么组织 Agent 需要的上下文，怎么在有限的上下文窗口里塞进足够的信息，那就是核心竞争力。

但同样没有长期壁垒。很快模型越来越强，上下文窗口越来越大，上下文工程的最佳实践也逐渐系统化——比如借助文件系统压缩上下文、利用渐进式披露（Progressive Disclosure）解决工具描述占用太多 token 的问题。这些方法现在大家都知道了。

第三阶段：Agent + Skills

现在是 Agent + Skills 的阶段。

Skills 解决的问题是：把特定工作流、特定领域的能力打包成可复用的「技能包」，让 Agent 之上可以长出丰富的应用生态。那些日常工作中琐碎但重复的任务，借助 Skill 的 Prompt 能力和工具能力，可以被高度自动化，带来巨大的效率提升。

投资 Skills 是短期红利。 Skills 作为一种具体形式，可能会被更强的模型能力取代——也许未来模型足够强，不再需要人类预先打包好的「技能包」，它自己就能规划出最优路径。

但问题来了：谁最能抓住这波短期红利？

不是吹 Skills 的自媒体，而是真正懂 Prompt、懂上下文工程的人和团队。他们能借助之前积累的经验，快速做出真正解决问题的 Skills。

投资的是能力，不是形式

Skills 本身不会成为长期壁垒，但你在 Skills 上投入的学习和实践，会成为你的长期壁垒。

这就像当年投资 Prompt 工程的人，后来更容易理解上下文工程；投资上下文工程的人，现在更容易做出好的 Skills。

每一波技术浪潮的「短期红利」，都是下一波浪潮的入场券。

所以我的建议是：不要纠结 Skills 会不会被取代，而是问自己：通过做 Skills，我能去解决什么问题？积累什么能力？这些能力在下一波浪潮里还有没有用？

如果答案是肯定的，那就值得投入。

result.text:
We just shipped a major app update that completes our entire TEE technology stack. The core implementation is finished, and we are now focused on deep integration and reorganizing the application for seamless, production ready performance. The first TEE powered services are expected to launch in February on the Sallar network as a powerful new utility layer for enterprises and individual users alike. 

TEEs solve a core modern challenge: processing sensitive data safely on systems you do not fully control, especially in the cloud. They originated in the early 2000s with ARM TrustZone for mobile devices and later expanded through major industry efforts such as Intel SGX and AMD SEV. Their main purpose is confidential computing: protecting data during active processing even when the host OS or cloud provider might be untrusted. 

A TEE works by creating a hardware isolated enclave, meaning shielded memory that only the code running inside can access. The host system can still manage resources or stop the process, but under the intended security model it cannot read enclave memory or silently alter enclave contents without breaking integrity guarantees. Remote attestation provides cryptographic proof that genuine hardware is in use and that the expected code is running. Only then should sensitive inputs such as API keys, customer information, or personal documents be sent into the enclave. 

For everyday phone users, TEE is quietly responsible for security features we rely on daily. Contactless payments are designed so payment credentials and signing operations are handled inside secure, hardware backed components, reducing exposure even if the main OS is compromised. Biometric templates are typically stored and matched inside secure environments, so apps and the broader system do not receive raw biometric data. Password manager keys, secure boot checks that help detect device tampering, and protected media playback commonly depend on TEE style isolation to keep sensitive operations separated and harder to extract. 

Real world examples include AWS Nitro Enclaves, which minimize attack surface by removing direct network access and persistent storage and communicating only with the parent instance, and AMD SEV, which encrypts full VM memory with dedicated per VM keys. These approaches differ in architecture, but the objective is the same - preserving the confidentiality and integrity of computation in hostile or untrusted hosting conditions. 

For Sallar users, this means businesses can run confidential workflows with provable, tamper resistant execution, while individuals get significantly safer personal data handling in practical tools. In February, we expect to deliver the first live TEE utilities, and we will expand the feature set step by step afterward.

据该知情人士称，就在会议期间，另外两名 Thinking Machines 的研究员 Luke Metz 和 Sam Schoenholz 抛出了重磅炸弹，他们分别在公司 Slack 上发帖称自己要辞职。

据该知情人士透露，Murati 对 Metz 和 Schoenholz 的消息似乎感到措手不及，而 Thinking Machines 的一些员工则被这接二连三爆出的三个离职消息惊呆了。

当天晚些时候，OpenAI 高管 Fidji Simo 宣布她的公司已聘用了这三名研究员（他们此前都曾在 OpenAI 工作，后来跳槽到 Thinking Machines），员工们的不安情绪开始加剧。

到了周四，又有两名 Thinking Machines 的员工——研究员 Lia Guy 和工程师 Ian O’Connell——告诉同事他们也要离开公司。在五名离职者中，有四人加入了 OpenAI。

通常情况下，大约 5% 的员工离职——Thinking Machines 在本周这波“叛逃”之前雇佣了大约 100 人——并不一定会引起严重担忧。但这些离职人员中包括该公司六位联合创始人中的两位，而且在此之前，第三位联合创始人 Andrew Tulloch 已于秋季离职去了 Meta Platforms。

据部分投资者称，这些事件让 Thinking Machines 的投资者感到不安。这家成立仅一年的初创公司目前只发布了一款产品，它正在进行一轮雄心勃勃的融资，旨在使公司估值达到 500 亿美元——这是其上一轮估值的五倍多。这些变动可能会使这一融资难以完成。

result.text:
Icarus International Consulting Group

The Regime Collapse Myth

Why Brute Force Rarely Topples Iran and What Actually Has to Break

Most people think regimes collapse because someone hits them hard enough.

That’s a comforting idea. It also gets you killed analytically.

A regime collapses when its internal system can no longer hold together. Airstrikes can accelerate that. Brute force alone almost never creates it.

If you want to understand Iran, start with that.

The ingredients required for
regime collapse

Forget protests. Forget trending videos. Forget the fantasy that one campaign produces a clean political outcome.

Collapse requires convergence. Several things have to fail at the same time, faster than they can be repaired.

Legitimacy has to crack in a specific way. People do not have to love the regime. They just have to believe there is no safer alternative. Collapse begins when hardship stops being interpreted as endurance and starts being interpreted as theft and humiliation, with no exit.

Coercive reliability has to wobble. Not in the sense that security forces disappear, but in the sense that enforcement becomes uneven, hesitant, or politically uncertain. The regime survives anger. It struggles when the coercive apparatus starts asking itself whether it will be paid, supplied, protected, and remembered.

Elite cohesion has to fracture. This is the most decisive ingredient and the one outsiders rarely see in time. When the ruling network stops trusting itself, actors begin hedging, competing, leaking, purging, and defecting. The public thinks the street is leading. In reality, the street becomes decisive only after the elite bargain is already breaking.

Resource flow has to seize. Cash, fuel, food, medicine, spare parts, patronage. The state can lie about almost anything except the availability of basics. When supply chains and payment systems begin failing, control becomes expensive and legitimacy burns faster.

Narrative control has to collapse. Every regime runs on a story that explains why people should tolerate pain. When the story fails, propaganda stops persuading and starts insulting. Over-explaining becomes a signal of fear, not strength.

That is the recipe. Not one pillar. Multiple pillars at once. That is what turns unrest into fragility and fragility into systemic failure.

Why brute force is seductive and why it disappoints

Brute force is attractive because it produces visible action and immediate numbers. Targets struck. Facilities damaged. Leaders threatened.

But brute force is not the same as regime collapse. It is a tool to create pressure, not a substitute for internal failure.

Even a highly effective campaign can do three things without toppling the system.

It can degrade capability. Iran can lose infrastructure and still retain political control.

It can raise cost. Costs hurt, but systems can absorb pain when elites remain cohesive and coercion remains reliable.

It can compress timelines. That is the real value of force. It accelerates stress and reduces the regime’s repair options.

If you are looking for collapse, those outcomes are not enough by themselves.

What the US and Israel would calculate if they relied on force alone

In a force centric approach, the objective is not to produce a cinematic collapse. The objective is to remove options and constrain behavior.

The first calculation is to reduce Iran’s confidence and coordination. If Iran cannot operate coherently under pressure, it cannot retaliate in an organized way and it cannot manage escalation cleanly. Confusion forces conservative choices and internal blame.

The second calculation is to reduce Iran’s ability to impose costs externally, especially through stand off means and partner networks. If Iran’s external leverage decreases, it becomes less able to deter follow on pressure.

The third calculation is to increase internal friction by stressing the systems that keep the coercive apparatus confident. When resources tighten and uncertainty spreads, internal security becomes more expensive and less predictable.

This is how force is used intelligently. It is not about winning the war in a week. It is about altering the internal math.

Why Iran is hard to bring down

Iran is not a fragile state with one center of gravity. It is a layered system designed for survival.

It has redundancy. Multiple institutions can do overlapping jobs. When one channel is hit, another adapts.

It has pain tolerance. The regime has lived with sanctions and isolation long enough to normalize hardship and build coping mechanisms.

It has ideological and coercive discipline. The state does not need broad love to survive. It needs a core that believes survival is existential and worth enforcing.

It has an externalization strategy. When pressure rises internally, the regime often redirects tension outward through calibrated regional escalation, creating bargaining leverage and distracting domestic focus.

Most importantly, Iran’s elites understand that collapse is the one outcome they must avoid at any cost. That creates cohesion under threat even when they compete under normal conditions.

This is why pure brute force struggles. It can break things. It cannot automatically break the system.

The strategic reality that decides everything

If you want to weaken Iran meaningfully, force has to translate into pillar stress.

If legitimacy erodes but coercion remains reliable, the regime survives.

If capability is degraded but elites remain cohesive, the regime adapts.

If resources tighten but narratives still work, the public endures.

Collapse begins only when several pillars fail together and repair capacity cannot keep up.

That is why regime collapse is rare. It requires convergence, not just impact.

The bottom line

Force can hurt Iran. It can constrain Iran. It can reduce Iran’s external reach and increase internal stress.

But Iran does not fall because things get destroyed.

Iran falls only if the internal system loses legitimacy, loses coercive reliability, loses elite cohesion, loses resource flow, and loses narrative control faster than it can repair them.

That is the difference between war and collapse.

And that is the difference between what looks decisive and what actually is.

Stay tuned for our upcoming analysis on the quiet war that decides everything — not on the battlefield, but between analysts, logisticians, and decision makers. From war and politics to business and sports, this is where the real game is played.

Icarus International Consulting Group

Kaiser Permanent just paid $550+ million to settle fraudulent billing accusations. Three qui tam whistleblowers are splitting $95 million. 

This claim involved aggressive "upcoding," the practicing of billing for a procedure that is more expensive than the specific procedure performed. Upcoding is common and involves judgments about the proper procedure code a doctor should use when there are similar codes for a treatment, and the reimbursement rate differs.

The fraud that is taking place in gender medicine involves brazen lying about the diagnosis the patient has, the sex of the patient, and completely fictional treatments - such as treating a breast removal on a teen girl as a gynocomastia removal on a boy, or justifying a puberty blocker implant as a treatment for non-existant precocious puberty or "tall stature".  

These are slam dunk cases, just waiting to be brought.
